I will admit it is very nice to see some sports games on Steam, and while I wasn't expecting a whole lot (I paid a whole 3 bucks for the game) I started off really enjoying the experiance but that turned quickly.

First, it does look like a nice game. I ran it at full everything and it never saw a chug or hiccup. The lighting was done well and you felt like you were actually boxing. Fighting in Russia saw snowflakes and in Vegas tonnes of flashing lights.

It's the little things that get to you after grinding the career mode. Firstly, it's a grind. If you win the first belt quickly you will need to replay the same tournement a few more times to earn the credits to level up your character to stand a chance in the later stages. But by the time you've done that the game's terrible AI flaws are very apparent and you won't need half the stats.

Start with a block, jab until your stamina is gone. Block and repeat. You have no actual need for uppercuts/crosses at all. No matter when you knock someone down, you get the same animation as they teleport to the middle of the ring and all replays have what I can figure as sneaker shoe sounds. This is boxing, not basketball.

But the MAJOR gripe I have. In BOXING you knock an opponent down 3 times... TKO. Real Boxing doesn't have that. I knocked one guy down 5 times in ONE ROUND...... That alone makes me not want to recommend the game. They spent more times working on the giggle of the breasts of the ring girl then googling how Boxing is done.

reviewText:
Do not be put off by all the negative reviews comparing this game to Electronic Art's Fight Night series of games. Fight Night is a AAA Sports title created by a developer who has a long history of developing boxing games, and it costed 6-times as much as this game. Of course Fight night going to be better, but that does not mean Real Boxing is not an enjoyable game worth it's $10 price tag.

Real Boxing Is more arcade than simulation, and there is not a lot of depth, but the action is fast paced and the multiplayer mode should be entertaining for hardcore boxing fans, at least in short spurts.  The single player career mode is basic, and there are not all that many different characters to fight against, but the mode exists. There are options for editing the appearance of your boxer, but you do not seem to be able to edit your boxer's name, which is a little bit annoying.
Aside from that, there are also the standard training mini games that you would expect to see in a boxing game. These mini games require you to press the right-stick in a certain direction in time with the on-screen cues. As you might guess the mini games become repetitive very quickly (but so did the mini games in fight Night).

The in-ring boxing action is not very simulation-like, but it's not exactly the mindless button-masher other reviews make it out to be.  You can throw all the punches you would expect (using either an anolog stick or the buttons) but there is no option for using dirty tactics such as headbutts or low blows. You can grab and clinch your opponent, but only when your energy drops below a certain level. Blocking is done with a single button, and it automatically blocks head or body shots as needed. You can also use a perfectly timed press of the block button to slip an opponents punch, creating a slow-motion effect allowing you an extra moment to throw a counter punch. There is no bobbing/weaving. There is no way to take a knee if your getting pummled, and there is no option for switching from orthodox to southpaw stance.

Pros:

- Fast paced action with easy to pick-up controls
- Decent looking graphics and presentation for a budget title
- Online multiplayer boxing matches
- Commentary is repetitive but sounds good for an arcade boxing experience
- it's the only (somewhat realistic) boxing game on Steam

Cons:

- Boxer movement/footwork is not very smooth
- Small roster of characters - No real world boxers
- Short/uninspired single-player career mode
- No matchmaking options for the online multiplayer mode

The bottom line is that it's not exactly a great game, but it's the best boxing game I have on my PC. The game will not have much appeal for most gamers, but hardcore boxing fans will probably find it fun being able to swap leather with other players now and then. It's not Fight Night Champion, but it's actually better than I had expected it to be.

I don't do many reviews, but I feel that this game is getting a lot of undesvered and unwarranted hate.

Let me just go ahead and say that this is not Fight Night. If you go into the game trying to compare it to that, you'll be disapointed to say the least. But, if you go into it looking for a game where you can waste a few hours every now and then beating on peoples faces, you'll quite enjoy this. This is a mobile port, but I was surprised to see that it's not your crappy run of the mill port that you usually get. The graphics are decent, not mind blowing, the controls are very responsive, and it just feels good when you land hits on the AI. There is a career mode where you can create your own character and fight various other fighters in a bracket for a belt. Leveling up your character is quite fun. The more fights you win, the more points you get to help level up your character. You can even buy perks for your character to get more of an advantage. The fights do sometimes come down to button mashing, but there are also tactics involved in being proficient at the game.

There is also multiplayer. I've played a couple matches and it's great so far. I got my butt kicked in both, but I admit that it was a fun experience. There was hardly any lag and I connected immediately when another person was found. I was surprised that the multiplayer even worked considering how some of the big AAA titles that get ported to PC can't even get their multiplayer to function properly.

Now, are there things that this game can improve on? Yes, of course. Many. Camera animations, voice acting, more mini games to help boost your characters stats, better character customization, and just overall a lot more content can be added to the game. But, if the devs continue to improve upon this game, it can turn out to be something truly fantastic.

Edit: Yes, you can play against your friends in multiplayer. They just have to be ready to accept the invite quickly. I expect that to be fixed very soon though.

reviewText:
Vivid Games mainly specialises in gaming apps for smart phones. Real Boxing is such a game (its sequel with its Rocky homage could be pretty cool and probably a more refined version of this game) which sports an arcade style boxing game that can be a good pastime if you are patient enough to wait for your next AAA game on your wishlist until its released or receives a substantial discount.

The problem is that Real Boxing was not a good pastime for me. I hated the frequent FPS drops, the mindless grinding that is needed otherwise you simply cannot complete the next tournament. Visiting the gym to increase your stamina, strength and speed is possible after every 5 matches (only participation counts; winning these is not mandatory) or you can spend your hard-earned credits to increase your stats right away. So, you go to a quick match then quit after 5 wins or you repeat the same tournament you have already completed - rinse and repeat.

What would I expect from a sports game?
- Realism
The game should reflect how the sport actually is in as many facets as possible.
- OR epicness
If realism isn't possible, show the best side instead.
- Different game modes
Unless the one game mode is REALLY detailed.
- Replayability / Skill-based
If it has no story, it should be skill-based. If it is skill-based, I expect it to replayable, so I can improve and feel better about myself. Sports games have no stories, so there you go.
- Exciting commentary / Great music
You hear it all the time, it should be enjoyable.
- Customization
If there's a career mode, I want my character to look goooood.

Real Boxing has none of the above. It has 2 game modes, which are essentially the same, you win by skilling your character, whose haircut and beard you can change ... and most fights are pretty much the same over and over again, including the commentary.

It feels like combos matter. Knocking a guy out within seconds with 7 hits is quite satisfying. The character model (singular) looks quite nice. A boob of the ring girl wiggles when she's applauding.

The mechanics of the game are pretty basic. You have a health bar and a stamina bar. The stamina bar determines the strength of your punches. It is short and regenerates quickly. Your health determines how many hits you can withstand before getting knocked down. There is a block and it will block any three consecutive punches where it will then break and place you in a stunned animation. The sway mechanic is a joke. You tap the block button when you see a punch coming for your head and if you timed it right, time will slow and give you a chance to swing back with bonus strength. Standing up from a knockdown is played the same way but the difficutly picks up after the 2nd time you go down.

reviewText:
Real Boxing is not a bad game but it has its fair share of flaws.

Let's start with the customization.You can choose from about 10-15 different hairstyles,sneakers,trousers and tattoos.I know this is not a Sims game but it would have been nice to have more customization.Another lackluster part of the game is its singleplayer experience.You can only win 3 belts.For each one you need to fight a number of opponents then qualify in a 4-man tournament to compete for the belt.It gets boring extremely fast and because of the lack of diversity you will feel like you fight the same guy over and over again.The game has only 3 arenas in which you can fight..again not much work done here.

Your boxer has 3 traits.Speed,Stamina and Strenght.You can improve those by playing 3 minigames for each one.It's a nice addition to the game and helps with the repetitivness aspect of the singleplayer.You can also buy 2 additional perks from a total of about 8..again not much to choose from.

The actual gameplay is actually fun and rewarding.You feel every punch and it has a nice clinching mechanic,giving you health if you win the clinch.Even if the game is fairly easy,you can enjoy it.

Real Boxing is a fairly decent game in terms of graphics but it has a weird way of registering punches.Whenever I watched replays of me knocking out an opponent,the jab/hook or uppercut didn't even connect most of the time.After awhile you will get bored not because the gameplay itself is boring but because the opponents have only three or four ways of falling to the ground or getting up.Even the music never changes which becomes annoying.Also after two or three matches you will probably just mute the commentator because he reapeats the same stuff over and over.It's a shame developers didn't put much effort into this game.

Overall I wouldn't reccommend Real Boxing for the price it has and even at a sale I would put it last in any list.You can enjoy the game for a few hours but it's lack of...everything makes the game not worth your money.If you are looking for a few hours of fun you can pick this up but if you want a longer and more engaging experience you can get that for the same price or even cheaper.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: THIS GAME IS NOT AS SHINY AS FIGHT NIGHT!  It's only $10 and developed by a smaller company.  If you want total boxing simulation fun time, buy a console and support EA's decsision to ignore the PC gamer community.

If you are in the mood for a boxing arcade game, Real Boxing is the game you are looking for.  It uses the Unreal engine and it's obvious imediately.  However, the use of the engine in this case is rather uniqe and it's neat to see a developer using the engine for something other than an FPS.  The single player mode is pretty short but it is useful for building up stats to kick ♥♥♥ at multiplayer mode. The training mini games are pretty repetitive and snooze-worthy but getting good at timing is pretty useful too in the long run.

Some reviews say that this game is nothing but a button mashing fest.  I have found that having a strategy and timing punches works a lot better than just button mashing, especially when your character's stats are low. The controls are pretty straight forward and are similar to other fighting games on PC.  Having a gamepad is ideal.

Don't let the bad reviews fool you.  This game is a pretty good experience for the money providing you aren't expecting a Fight Night clone.  It's kind of a shiny, 3D version of Super Punch Out so if you loved that as a kid, consider giving Real Boxing a try.

The fact that this is a handheld/mobile port is frighteningly obvious. While there is a lack of boxing games on PC, this game is not up to standard. The animations are very poor and the gameplay is poorly thought out. Career mode is very skinny with three mini-games that you can only occasionally use to train your boxer, and the title fights are insanely easy on the first circuit and insanely hard on the second circuit. Progression is really repeatiing the same low-level circuit until you can get enough cash to boost your stats to survive getting hit in the next level.

The fighting mechanics lack any flow or depth. You cannot throw combinations, so boxing is simply a matter of tapping the jab or hook button. Blocking is a one-button affair, and while you can punch through a block, you don't have enough stamina to exploit it. Hit reactions are awkward - punches don't connect to the opponent, so if the opponent is staggering, your punches are sure to miss, which is very unintuitive. The counterattack system seems like something nice, but it's really just an opportunistic slow-mo which is botched by the lack of fluid fighting.

The characters are all the same. There are no distinctions between boxing styles, so it's really just a slugfest. It's disappointing to see a Real Boxing" title feature nothing that makes boxing real.

reviewText:
TL:DR - Not a boxing sim, but an arcade beat-'em-up. 6/10

'Real Boxing' is exactly the opposite of what it says on the tin. This is not, in any way, shape, or form, a real boxing game.

First things first, the game doesn't help itself by having a shoddy set up. The game defaults of medium graphical settings regardless of your rig when you first start the game. Do yourself a favour, ignore the people moaning on the forums, go into the settings, set everything to max and switch blood on, then restart the game. The game looks at least on par with Fight Night Champion, possibly better, though it's hard to tell as this has a more cartoony aesthetic that makes a direct comparison difficult. For a budget title, the graphics are more than adequte.

It doesn't help that this was obviously put together by people with no real knowledge of boxing. A 'right jab' is not a jab, it's a straight cross. Common terminology here people.

So, the boxing itself. This game stinks of 'gotta match budget Fight Night' all the way through;

Training mini-games? Check, but they're ripped straight out of a late 90's early 00's copy Dance Dance Revolution and require you to press the right button when it flashes green in a box, at the right rhythm. The training teaches you absolutely nothing useful for in the game, it's bashing buttons to increase your stats.
AI that struggles to overcome a simple jab-jab-straight combination? Check, with the added bonus of having an AI that only seems to throw Hooks/Uppercuts, it's easy to play an outside fighter and jab them to death. Speaking of styles...
Even less of a distinction between the styles than Fight Night has. No stances, no punch styles, as far as i'm aware no southpaws, no footwork, no leaning beyond a rudimentary 'press button to dodge'.
Unlimited hold button to block? Check. Slightly better than Fight Night in that 3 punches will break the block, ruined by the fact the canned stagger animation ALWAYS takes them out of the range of any of your punches, meaning breaking the block is essentially worthless. Speaking of animations...
Animations are horrible. Knockouts could have come from Knockout Kings on the old N64, no physics, no impact, just a guy falling over like a tree. Tiiiiimbeeeeeeer!
Canned, nonsensical commentary? Check! My guy has not won the title, it was a standard tournament match with nothing on the line. 4 jabs in a row is NOT a 'tricky combination', a straight cross is NOT a 'nice jab'.
Bad blood effects? Check! After the bad blood developed in the Fight Night community after EA rebalanced the blood effects with the bare knuckle DLC, this game looks like it's been made by a group of 15 year olds who think every boxing match should have arterial blood sprays coming from every hook. The ring gets spattered with bright red blood, dripping from each fighter by the end of the first round. Speaking of damage....
There is no inter-round mechanics. No trainer tips, no swelling/cut management, no punch stats. Your health is auto-healed between rounds and you have no real idea of how you're doing, as there are no colour commentator scoring cards.

There is also no referee. This means no fouls, no point deductions, unlimited clinches, no rabbit punching, etc. The clinches are especially annoying, as there is no end if you and the AI are evenly matched. It's another pointless minigame.

There are some pros for the game however. Punch stats are generally realistic, as your fighter will be winded after throwing 4-5 punches that land, or missing 1-2 punches. This leaves a realistic rhythm of jab-jab-hook/cross/uppercut before backing off again and finding a new angle. This is however ruined by the lack of footwork etc. meantioned above. It is also ruined by the fact that Stamina is permanent and non-degrading. This means body shots have no value whatsoever. It also elaves something to be desired when you're pushing for a KO, as there is no way to keep up real sustained pressure.

Overall, this is an above average game. It's very reasonably prices, it looks and sounds fine, while the gameplay has been made by people with no real understanding of boxing. Treat it as a arena based quick beat-em-up, with 3, 1 minute rounds, and it's passable.

Better yet, download an emulator and play Fight Night Champion.

6/10.

Edit: Upon completing the game, several achievements did not unlock. 3/10 if they don't sort this basic functionality out.

After 19hr of gameplay.
Hi all.
Here i am after 19hr (and a 10hr long session), really happy with the game (addictive!).

I don't know the Fight Night series, but this game alone is worth if you like boxing or are interested in fight games, and you enjoy it for what it is (no real boxers, not really an AAA game - the game is a port from mobile devices). Plus it's the only boxing game in steam that i know.

Combat is more toward simulation than arcade gameplay, where you can't simply smash buttons to win. You need to think your strategy for the whole round, and the following ones. I found the mechanics equilibrated (although dodging is a little irritating, but adds a random factor to the combat).

Playing tournaments to grind stats could be a long run or boring for some people, but for me it's fun (always wanting more and more!), while learning how to play deeper at the same time.

In my case were around 17h to win all tournaments (3) without any KO/lost match (leveling stats before to a little more than my adversaries). Although the last tournament is always hard.

Graphics/animations are great, the sound/music is ok, the feeling of contact is really well done.
I highly recommend the game, i repeat, for what it is. It's my humble opinion.

reviewText:
Real Boxing is a solid game marred by a few problems. The announcer is hilariously obnoxious. I really wish there was more and better boxer customization. There is no real variation in frame or facial structure. I can't play a slick, wiry bantamweight that looks like Rigondeaux - I have to look like competition-fit Kai Greene, with my choice of gear, facial features, and skin colour. You'd think that with how much variation there is in the build, height, and reach of boxers, it would at least be addressed in the game. But nope, every boxer uses the same re-skinned model.

Graphical gripes aside, when I actually play it as I believe it was intended, Real Boxing is such a fun game. There are many elements to the strategy of boxing that they successfully incorporated game mechanics for. If you choose, every fight can be a chess match, with specific punches chosen to counter whatever they throw, fun and rewarding micro with timing headslips, and a range system that ends up modeling boxing footwork fairly well.

Unfortunately, aspects of the game are broken -the stamina system and the stun / combo mechanic. These mechanics are supposed to reward skilled play; ideally you go in to trade 3 or 4 accurate and carefully chosen punches, then cover up and get back out of range. Unfortunately it is vastly more efficient to select the right perks and run forward while repeatedly jabbing your opponent to unconsciousness. Run at them, jab the guard until it breaks, jab them while they're stunned. Rinse, repeat. Boring.

There is multiplayer and I have not yet dared. Who knows though, maybe amist all the cheese and jab spam, something resembling Real Boxing might happen.

“Real Boxing” is a surprisingly fun action-boxing game. I’ve never played “Fight Night” (I don’t own a console), but I’ve played many others over the years (all the way back to Atari 2600 boxing!). From my perspective, “Real Boxing” is the real deal, a legitimate boxing game that’s exciting and involving.

If you’re a boxing purist like myself, however, you will notice some missing elements of actual boxing, and some aspects are quite unrealistic. I’ll list the CONS of the game first:

CONS:
-  no body attacks. That is, no punches at all to the midsection (stomach, below the belt, etc.) This is an entirely head-hunting game.

- the controls are a bit awkward, no matter which option you choose (keyboard/mouse, joystick, etc.)  It will take some getting used to.

- Opponents all fight in the same style, with only their stats (strength, stamina, and speed) making the difference in difficulty.

-  the “clinching” system is frustrating and unrealistic. It’s a button-mashing exercise that can last the entire round! No ref will break it up. And usually, you will lose the clinch game against the computer opponent.

- There’s no three-knockdown rule. I’ve battered opponents who’ve gotten up from knockdowns five times in one round!

- Once you’ve won all three champoinship tournaments, there’s little incentive to keep playing the single player mode. You've beaten the game.

- In multiplayer mode, you’ll get massacred by other players online!!!

PROS:

-  The action is fast-paced, tense, and suitably tactical. Keep your guard up! Jab, stick, and move!

- The graphics are quite good. Not “Fight Night,” but still very attractive and well-animated.

- You feel like you’re boxing! (Once you get past the “no body shots” limitation).

- The training mini-games are effective, if a little frustrating at times.

- You can't just blast through the game without building up you're stats over time. You will have to take on some lesser quick fight" opponents to gain enough ring experience (and stats). Otherwise

reviewText:
More a brawler than a boxing sim, this is no Fight Night, but given the woeful lack of PC boxing games, I'll take it. My only real fault with the game is it's clunky as crap sometimes. You can dodge an incoming punch, but the movement is sometimes too clunky for you to move in and counter in time. Fight Night (my favourite boxing game franchise, so naturally my go-to comparison, I make no apologies) offered very fluid controls, this feels much heavier and .. well just heavy, and I felt like I was moving on a grid (like the original tomb raider, you know what I mean), it really broke immersion and I never felt I was fully in control of my guy.
That said, very satisfying to KO folk. It's interesting though, the fewer rounds you set it to play as, the more damage you'll do. My first match I set to 15 rounds, and I ended up going the distance without getting the opponent's health bar down halfway. Set it to three hours, however, and you'll get two KOs per round easily. For the best balance of realism and arcade brawler I guess go with ten rounds.
Minigames to level up your boxer are repetitive but more difficulty is added to these too as you go through the escalating boxing tournaments, which was a pleasant surprise that caught me off-guard. Sadly, these involve not just the buttons but the analogue sticks, and I often screwed up because I find it difficult to judge an angle to aim the stick at, so when it wanted the right stick to go up to the right at 45 degrees, I often missed it by going too far 90 degrees, or vice versa, which was frustrating and felt like a cheap fail.
In lieu of more polished boxing sim alternatives this will serve well enough, but it could use a bit of polish. More variety in unlocks wouldn't go amiss either, the gear and especially the hair and stuff is far too limited, and you stand a good chance of fighting a clone of yourself, which is amusing but kinda weird :P

reviewText:
If you have played previous AAA boxing games, I don't recommend this game for you.

If you haven't and want to have a boxing game for your PC, go for it.

SCORE: 7/10

Real Boxing has the basics of boxing mechanics from jabs, straights, uppers, hooks, clinch, dodge, block and counters. The graphics are great. It has a shop menu where you can buy items like boxing gloves, shorts and shoes. As i said earlier, it has the basic boxing mechanics which makes the gameplay repetitive especially when you're up against tougher opponents which takes a longer time to defeat and having to do the same combo or dodging becomes boring. Because of this you can't develop a deeper and adaptive play style of being an in-fighter, out-fighter or a mixture of both. It could add powered punches (haymakers), step-in/out, side steps, specifics blocks and feints to remedy its limited boxing mechanics. Also the footwork in the game is not smooth and sometimes frustrating.

reviewText:
TL;DR
I recommend you to try it, just for the sake of playing an almost forgotten genre, but it will bore you quickly.

Longer version.

The game is gorgeous looking (for an indie) and decent sfx, you do have some nice details on the face (blood, cuts etc) and you even start hearing noises when you get hit hard, some blood splatter in the screen.

The boxing itself isnt really that bad. Not that strategic, but fun semi arcade boxing.

Combat its simple, 6 different buttons to hit (jab, hook, uppercut) x 2 hands, thats for the headshots, you have to press an aditional button to land it on the body. One tap of a button to dodge an incoming hit, keep pressing for a block.
If you dodge a punch succesfully, you regain some stamina and the game gets into slowmo, allowing you to counter attack, but the AI can also dodge and counter, so you can get some really nice chains in slowmo.

You do not block specific parts of your body, its automagical, and not so strategic.

And thats about it about the combat, not that complicated to start trowing some punches at the IA. Its decent enough, when you start, but then income the problems.

When you start, you have about the same stats than your opponents. Your punches look and seem powerful, they do damage, though you can only hit 2-3 times since you will drain all your stamina, you have to wait to fill it again (few seconds without receiving hits or dodging a punch). After a couple fights, you will get some quick wins.

But the scaling is terribly. You cannot train whenever you want or have cash for it, this only happens every few fights
and you can only train once per stat. If you have leftover money, you can pay for the increase of each stat (what?).

Once you finish your first tournament, the stat difference becomes abysmal. You do virtually no damage, while your opponent hits a jab and does like 5 times the damage you did with a perfectly timed uppercut. Stamina wise is about the same, you can throw 4-5 punches now, but they can throw a flurry of punches. And unlike you, when you are hitting your opponent with a combination, they do regen stamina.

So at this point you practically are negated a KO fight (seriously, your opponent ends 100% hp every single fight) you do have to box and win by desition, so it gets boring real quick.

Training itself its boring as well. you just have to press a button at the right time, each training its about the same as the other one, the only difference its the pace at you have to press the buttons.

If you are a fan of boxing, well, you have like 1hr gameplay on this one. If you have tolerance for boring fights, then prepare yourself, you will hit with wet noodles and have to win most fights by desition (unless you want to make some grinding in already won tournaments).

reviewText:
I have to say I have mixed feelings about this game.  It's a fun game if you're just looking to fill a few hours for $5, but you really can't expect much beyond that.  The AI is predictable and easy and there doesn't seem to be much variation from one boxer to the next.  The challenge does get tighter as you move up in the tournaments, but if you decide to restart tournaments that you've already won, you can grind your way to the top skills very easily and completely decimate the AI.

This game has a lot of potential.  Unfortunately, the lack of players online makes what could be a decent MP boxing game a rather short and less than stellar single player game in career mode.  While, I'm sure it would be more rewarding to not grind it out and actually beat the game in succession, there just doesn't seem to be much of a point unless you want to balance out the challenge and perhaps bother collecting all of the achievements.

Despite all of this, I did have fun even despite the grind for 7 hours which isn't bad considering the $5 price tag.  While, I do wish there were more players online and a more varied single player career mode, I can't say this isn't worth buying or playing because it is.

In conclusion, I am in fact recommending this game especially at its current price.  I would definitely be willing to pay $20 for a more polished sequel with better AI and more players to take advantage of the multiplayer mode.

reviewText:
2 hours, finished the game with max stats and all unlocks. Waste of $8 wish steam offered refunds for abandoned projects and 1/4 finished games.

Interaction:
Was hoping for a game like EA fight night where dodging and blocking as well as good combos would win the day (i.e. skill). Dodge is the same button as block, press to dodge (i.e. tap spam) and hold to block (i.e. wtf i pressed dodge not block... oh you gotta tap spam to dodge). Took me about 30 matches before i figured out how dodging worked. Even after I figured it out, it's not interactive. You dont dodge incoming blows, you predict them before any form of movement has ensued.

Apparently this is a mobile app port, makes sense as playing on PC you can't react to anything in real time as i explained above. Its like a dance simulator except minus the visual cue's. If you react while a punch is being thrown its too late. You need to react before the punch is being thrown, like some form of anticipatory foreplay. This made me really sad as it removed all tactical gameplay.

Gameplay:
So playing through single player, you will notice STATS MEAN EVERYTHING.

There are 3 main stats (ikr way to many to manage :P) Strength ((how much damage you do, opponents strength stat affects this) ie. 100% strength will do way more damage vs 68% strength than 92%)

Stamina ((how quickly you gas out) doesn't really affect ♥♥♥♥ as even with max stamina vs low stamina you can only throw 3-4 punches before being gassed, it only really affects recovery speed in a high vs low stat (like strength as above))

and speed (who hits first) this doesnt really affect much either as i will explain later. Doesnt matter who hits 1st unless its against high level bots who can dodge like it has its own button :P

For instance you can have better Stamina and speed yet be losing by 3 points of strength, the person you are fighting will hit you and do 3 to 6 times as much damage (ie. 10 vs 30 or 60 damage). even though you are hitting 1st and more times.

Punching doesn't involve any tactics either, as there is a generic high block and no real dodge function. So if you both swing both will hit (depending on punch choice), then it comes down to stamina or strength. i.e. Who can punch for longer or who hits harder. So if you have more speed and stamina you can do 1 more hit at less damage against someone who does more damage in less hits with strength i.e. as above ^

So playing through all the single player if you just level up before proceeding you can come out and 1st round KO everyone by just swinging then block recover stamina and swing (rinse and repeat)

Character development:
As stated stats progession is the main point of the game. If you try to play through the game and do the minigames every 5 matches you will have a bad time. Mainly because the minigames are horrible. You are better off just restarting the tournaments and buying all your stats with the cash winnings.

Character creation:
You can choose between about 8 premade characters and where you are from and your name. Def next level for a mobile 99 cent app port.

Multiplayer:
finished the game, decided to try multiplayer got some poor guy without 100% stats. Noticed a lot of lag and blackscreen between the knockdown screens i.e. 3-4 seconds. Also noticed a lot of delay, so im guessing matchmaking isnt done on ping.

All in All:
Wasn't impressed, the game offered no challenge and when it did (i.e. understats vs higher levels) the lack of an effective counter (i.e. dodge) really made it a pushing isht uphill problem. I actually like playing fightnight against way OP opponents as you could still dodge and outskill them, This game offers none of that depth. Its a 3d SNES port of mike tysons punchout.
